issues.title: Coolant Pipe Failures
issues.symptoms: Coolant loss, overheating warning, coolant puddles, sweet smell, temperature fluctuation
issues.description: The 991 continues to use plastic coolant pipes in the cooling system. These pipes run from the front radiators to the rear engine and are subjected to heat cycling and vibration. They can crack, especially at connection points, causing coolant loss. The coolant transfer pipe in particular is a known failure point.
fixes: Replace plastic coolant pipes with aluminum upgrade
Coolant transfer pipe replacement (common failure)
Replace expansion tank if showing age
Water pump replacement as preventive maintenance
Flush and refill with proper coolant mix

repairCosts.notes: Continues plastic pipe tradition. Aluminum upgrades available.

issues.title: Carbon Buildup on Intake Valves (DFI Engines)
issues.symptoms: Rough idle, misfires, reduced power, poor fuel economy, hesitation under load
issues.description: All 991 engines use direct fuel injection (DFI), meaning fuel doesn't wash over the intake valves. Carbon deposits accumulate on the valve backs and intake ports, restricting airflow and affecting engine performance. This is a maintenance item requiring periodic walnut blasting, typically every 50,000-80,000 miles depending on driving style.
fixes: Walnut shell blasting (standard solution)
Chemical treatments (less invasive but less effective)
Catch can installation to reduce oil vapor deposits
Use Top Tier fuel with good detergent packages
Spirited driving helps but doesn't eliminate buildup

repairCosts.notes: All 991 engines are DFI. Walnut blasting needed periodically.

issues.title: PDK Transmission Issues
issues.symptoms: Harsh shifts, jerky low-speed operation, shuddering, warning lights, delayed engagement
issues.description: The PDK dual-clutch transmission is generally reliable but can develop issues. Low-speed jerkiness, especially when cold, is common and may be normal for the system. More serious issues include clutch pack wear, mechatronic unit failures, and software glitches. PDK fluid should be serviced despite Porsche's 'lifetime' fill claim.
fixes: PDK fluid change (recommended every 50,000-60,000 miles)
Software updates to address shift quality
Clutch adaptation reset via PIWIS diagnostic
Clutch pack replacement if severely worn
Mechatronic unit repair for electronic issues

repairCosts.notes: Fluid service recommended every 50-60k despite 'lifetime' fill.

issues.title: PASM Suspension Damper Failures
issues.symptoms: PASM warning light, harsh ride, damper leaking, clunking noises, uneven handling
issues.description: PASM (Porsche Active Suspension Management) dampers use electronic valving to adjust stiffness. These dampers can fail, usually by leaking or developing electrical issues. A failed damper triggers a warning light and the system may default to a fixed setting. PASM dampers are expensive compared to conventional shocks.
fixes: Diagnose with Porsche diagnostic tool (PIWIS)
Replace failed PASM damper (OEM or remanufactured)
Some owners convert to quality coilovers when multiple fail
Check wiring and connectors before replacing damper
Remanufactured dampers available at reduced cost

issues.title: Oil Consumption Concerns
issues.symptoms: Low oil warnings, need to add oil between changes, blue smoke on startup, oil smell
issues.description: Some 991.1 models exhibit higher than expected oil consumption. Porsche's stated acceptable consumption is up to 1 quart per 1,000 miles, which many owners find excessive. Direct injection, high compression, and tight tolerances contribute. Tracking oil level is important, and the car should not be run low on oil.
fixes: Monitor oil level regularly using on-board system
Keep oil level in proper range (not overfilled)
Some owners report improvement with different oil brands
Severe consumption may indicate piston ring issues
Compression and leak-down test for diagnosis

repairCosts.notes: 991.1 may consume oil. Monitor and top up. Severe cases need diagnosis.

issues.title: Twin-Turbo Specific Issues (991.2)
issues.symptoms: Boost inconsistency, wastegate rattle, turbo whine, check engine light, reduced power
issues.description: The 991.2 moved to twin-turbo engines for all models. While generally reliable, the turbos can develop issues including wastegate rattle, actuator problems, and seal failures. Turbo feed and drain lines need monitoring. These engines are more complex than the naturally aspirated 991.1.
fixes: Wastegate actuator adjustment or replacement
Turbo oil line inspection and replacement
Intercooler inspection for leaks
Boost leak testing if low power complaints
Proper warm-up and cool-down for turbo longevity

repairCosts.notes: 991.2 twin-turbo. Wastegate rattle and boost issues.

issues.title: Convertible Top Issues (Cabriolet)
issues.symptoms: Slow operation, error messages, hydraulic leaks, top doesn't complete cycle, fabric wear
issues.description: The 991 Cabriolet's power top system is complex and can develop age-related issues. Hydraulic pump wear, microswitch failures, and ram seal leaks cause operational problems. The fabric top can wear at stress points, and the rear window can develop issues. Proper operation and storage help longevity.
fixes: Hydraulic system inspection and fluid top-off
Hydraulic pump replacement if failing
Microswitch adjustment or replacement
Top fabric replacement for worn or damaged tops
System reset procedure after battery work

issues.title: Electric Steering Column Issues
issues.symptoms: Creaking noise, steering feel inconsistency, steering wheel off-center, warning lights
issues.description: The 991 uses an electric power steering system. While generally reliable, some owners report issues with the steering column producing creaking noises, especially when turning at low speeds. There can also be software-related issues affecting steering feel or causing warning messages.
fixes: Steering column lubrication for creaking
Software update for steering feel issues
Steering rack inspection if play detected
Steering angle sensor recalibration
Full diagnosis with Porsche diagnostic tool

repairCosts.notes: Creaking from column. Lubrication often helps.

guides.title: Complete Suspension Refresh
guides.description: Full front and rear suspension rebuild for the 991's sophisticated multi-link design including PASM service considerations.
steps: Raise vehicle on jack stands at all four corners.
Remove wheels and photograph suspension.
For PASM cars: diagnose failed dampers before ordering parts.
Soak all bolts with penetrating oil.
Front: Remove sway bar links (48 ft-lbs), tie rod ends (48 ft-lbs).
Remove control arm bolts (89 ft-lbs) and ball joint (56 ft-lbs).
For struts: mark camber, remove upper mount nuts (23 ft-lbs), pinch bolt (65 ft-lbs).
Use spring compressor to replace strut mount.
Rear: Remove control arms (81 ft-lbs inner, 74 ft-lbs eccentric).
Replace PASM dampers if leaking or failed.
Install all new components with correct torque specs.
Install wheels and lower vehicle.
Professional alignment mandatory - 991 is very alignment-sensitive.
tips: The 991 uses electronic steering - sensitive to alignment.
PASM dampers fail more often than conventional shocks.
Remanufactured PASM units offer good value.
991.2 turbo models have stiffer suspension - same procedure.
warnings: PASM requires PIWIS to calibrate after replacement.
Center-lock wheel torque is 443 ft-lbs - different tool required.

guides.title: Rust Prevention and Inspection
guides.description: Rust inspection guide for the 991, which is fully galvanized but still requires attention to water intrusion and cooling system components.
steps: The 991 is fully galvanized - structural rust is rare.
Clean undercarriage before inspection.
Check front trunk for water - electronics located here.
Clear sunroof and frunk drain tubes.
Inspect coolant transfer pipe - known failure point.
Check LED headlights for condensation (less common than HID).
Examine rocker panels and door bottoms.
Check wheel wells for debris damage.
Surface rust: wire brush, convert, prime, topcoat.
Apply cavity wax to hollow sections annually.
Inspect all cooling system plastic for cracks.
tips: 991s are well-protected - most issues are water intrusion.
Coolant transfer pipe failure is main concern, not rust.
LED headlights less prone to moisture than older HID.
Annual Fluid Film application provides protection.
warnings: Coolant leak can cause overheating before rust.

guides.title: Electrical System Service
guides.description: Complete electrical service for the 991 covering ignition, PDK service, and common electronic issues.
steps: Begin with full diagnostic scan - 991 requires PIWIS for many functions.
For coils: open engine lid, disconnect and remove.
991.2 turbo: inspect wastegate actuators for rattle.
For PDK service: drain and fill with Pentosin FFL-2.
Reset clutch adaptation via PIWIS after PDK service.
For battery replacement: register new battery in DME.
For steering column creak: lubricate steering column.
Clean all ground points.
Clear codes and verify repairs.
Perform adaptations as required.
tips: 991 requires PIWIS for many diagnostic functions.
PDK fluid should be changed despite 'lifetime' claim.
Battery registration mandatory or charging issues result.
991.2 wastegate rattle is common - not always serious.
warnings: Battery must be registered in DME.
PDK service requires proper fluid - no substitutes.

guides.title: Interior Restoration
guides.description: Complete interior refresh for the 991 covering leather care, PCM system, and common wear items.
steps: Document condition with photos.
Clean leather with dedicated cleaner.
Fill cracks with leather filler, sand, dye.
Condition all leather surfaces.
Assess steering wheel - rewrap if worn.
Replace worn boots and knobs.
Replace cabin air filter.
Clean HVAC vents with brushes.
Address seat bolster wear.
Replace door seals if wind noise present.
Update PCM software if available.
Apply UV protectant to exposed surfaces.
tips: 991 uses high-quality leather that responds well to care.
Sport Plus seats have more aggressive bolsters.
PCM touch screen can benefit from protector.
HVAC clicking indicates blend actuator failure.
warnings: Steering wheel has airbag - disconnect battery.
PCM updates require dealer or compatible tool.

diyGuides.title: Oil Change
diyGuides.description: Complete oil and filter change for 991.1 and 991.2 engines.
diyGuides.interval: Every 10,000 miles or 1 year (some owners prefer 5,000-7,500)
tools: Ramps or jack and jack stands
steps: Warm the engine for 2-3 minutes to thin the oil for better drainage.
Drive onto ramps or raise vehicle and support on jack stands.
Locate the oil drain plug on the bottom of the engine case - 19mm socket.
Position drain pan and remove drain plug - be careful of hot oil.
While oil drains, locate the cartridge oil filter housing on top of engine.
Remove oil filter cap using 76mm cap wrench - turn counterclockwise.
Pull out old filter element and discard. Clean housing interior.
Allow oil to drain completely (15+ minutes for thorough drain).
Install new crush washer on drain plug and reinstall - torque to 37 ft-lbs (50 Nm).
Install new filter element and replace o-ring on cap (lube with fresh oil).
Reinstall filter cap and torque to 19 ft-lbs (26 Nm).
Lower vehicle and add approximately 8.5-9 quarts of 0W-40 full synthetic.
Start engine and check for leaks at drain plug and filter housing.
Check oil level using the dashboard display - add oil to proper level.
Reset the service interval in the instrument cluster.
tips: 991.1 cars may consume oil - monitor level between changes and top up as needed.
Use only oils meeting Porsche A40 specification (Mobil 1, Motul 8100, etc.).
991.2 turbo models are especially important to use quality oil.
Don't overfill - check level after running engine and letting it sit.
Save some fresh oil in your trunk for top-ups on 991.1 cars.

diyGuides.title: Brake Pad Replacement
diyGuides.description: Front and rear brake pad replacement with electronic sensor reset.
diyGuides.interval: Every 20,000-40,000 miles depending on driving style
tools: 7mm hex/Allen socket for caliper guide pins
Brake piston retractor (rear requires screw-in type)
steps: Loosen wheel bolts slightly before raising the vehicle.
Raise and safely support vehicle on jack stands at designated lift points.
Remove wheel bolts (19mm) and remove wheel.
Disconnect the brake pad wear sensor connector from the caliper.
Remove the two caliper guide pin bolts (7mm hex).
Swing the caliper upward and secure it - don't let it hang by the hose.
Remove old brake pads and note wear sensor position.
Clean caliper bracket slides and pad contact areas with brake cleaner.
Inspect rotor thickness and condition - replace if below minimum spec.
Front: Compress piston straight back into caliper using piston tool.
Rear: Rotate piston clockwise while pressing - requires screw-in tool.
Apply thin brake lubricant to pad backing plates and slide areas.
Install new pads with wear sensor on inner pad (inboard side).
Swing caliper back down and reinstall guide pin bolts - torque to 25 ft-lbs.
Reconnect wear sensor connector.
Reinstall wheel and torque bolts to 118 ft-lbs (160 Nm) in star pattern.
Pump brake pedal multiple times to seat pads before driving.
tips: 991 has electronic brake pad monitoring - sensors are single-use, replace with pads.
After pad replacement, the warning may stay on until cleared with diagnostic tool.
PCCB (ceramic composite brakes) require dealer service - don't attempt DIY.
Bed new pads properly: multiple moderate stops, then light driving to cool.
Open fluid reservoir cap before compressing pistons to prevent overflow.

diyGuides.title: Spark Plug Replacement
diyGuides.description: Replace spark plugs on the 991 flat-six engine (NA and turbo).
tools: 5/8" (16mm) spark plug socket with rubber insert
steps: Allow engine to cool completely - critical for aluminum cylinder heads.
Remove any engine covers for better access to coil packs.
Disconnect the electrical connector from each ignition coil by pressing the release tab.
Remove the coil pack mounting bolt (10mm) from each of the six coils.
Pull each coil pack straight up and out of the spark plug tube.
Use compressed air to blow any debris out of the spark plug wells.
Using a 5/8" spark plug socket with extension, remove each plug.
Inspect each removed plug for abnormal wear, oil fouling, or damage.
Check spark plug gap on new plugs (should be factory preset).
Apply a thin coating of anti-seize to new plug threads (keep off electrode).
Thread new plugs in by hand first to prevent cross-threading.
Torque plugs to 22 ft-lbs (30 Nm) - do not overtighten.
Apply dielectric grease to inside of coil pack boots.
Reinstall coil packs and torque mounting bolts to 7 ft-lbs (10 Nm).
Reconnect all coil pack connectors until they click.
tips: 991.2 turbo models may have slightly different access - same basic procedure.
Use only OEM or equivalent quality plugs (NGK or Bosch).
Never install plugs in a hot engine - severe risk of thread damage.
If plug is hard to turn, stop and apply penetrating oil - don't force it.
Check for any stored fault codes after completion if you have a scanner.

diyGuides.title: Coolant Flush
diyGuides.description: Drain and refill cooling system with fresh coolant to prevent corrosion.
tools: G40 or G48 coolant concentrate (Porsche approved)
Coolant funnel or vacuum fill tool
steps: Allow engine to cool completely - never open cooling system when hot.
Locate the coolant drain on the radiator and position drain pan.
Open the expansion tank cap to allow air in and speed draining.
Open radiator drain and allow coolant to drain completely.
Inspect drained coolant color and condition - rust indicates problems.
Close drain and add distilled water to flush the system.
Run engine to operating temperature with heater on max to circulate.
Allow to cool, drain flush water, and repeat until water runs clear.
Close all drains and prepare 50/50 coolant mix (or use pre-mixed).
Slowly fill system through expansion tank - this takes patience.
Start engine with expansion tank cap off to allow air to escape.
Run engine to operating temperature and top off as air purges.
Check for leaks at all connections and hoses.
Install expansion tank cap and verify proper coolant level when cold.
Check level again after driving and engine has cooled.
tips: Use only Porsche-approved G40 or G48 coolant - mixing types causes problems.
The 991's long coolant runs make air purging challenging - take your time.
A vacuum fill system makes this job much easier and faster.
Inspect plastic coolant pipes while system is drained - replace if cracked.
This is a good time to replace thermostat if original and over 60k miles.

engine.name: Service direct fuel injectors
engine.description: Clean/replace if misfiring or rough idle

engine.name: Replace oil separator/AOS
engine.description: Can cause smoke and rough running

engine.name: Replace air filter elements
engine.description: Dual air filters - one per bank

cooling.name: Inspect plastic coolant pipes
cooling.description: Replace with aluminum if showing age

transmission.name: PDK transmission service
transmission.description: Fluid and filter change every 60k miles

interior.name: Restore seat bolsters
interior.description: Sport seats wear on driver side

electrical.name: Service PSE pump
electrical.description: Powers spoiler and deck lid actuators

buyersGuide.overview: The Porsche 991 (2012-2019) represents the modern evolution of the 911, with increased dimensions, improved technology, and the introduction of turbocharged engines across the range in 991.2. The 991 offers exceptional performance (350-700 hp depending on variant), modern amenities, and excellent reliability. While the naturally aspirated 991.1 engines are praised by purists, the turbocharged 991.2 offers more everyday power. GT3, GT3 RS, and GT2 RS variants continue to set benchmarks for track performance.

variants.name: Carrera / Carrera S (991.1)
variants.description: Naturally aspirated with 3.4L (350 hp) or 3.8L (400 hp). Purist choice with high-revving character.

variants.name: Carrera / Carrera S (991.2)
variants.description: Turbocharged 3.0L producing 370-420 hp. More power everywhere but different character.

variants.name: Carrera 4 / 4S
variants.description: All-wheel drive variants. Widebody styling standard on 4S. More stable in all conditions.

variants.name: GT3 / GT3 RS
variants.description: Track-focused with naturally aspirated 4.0L producing 475-520 hp. PDK or manual available. Exceptional drivers' cars.

variants.name: Turbo / Turbo S
variants.description: Twin-turbo with 520-580 hp. AWD standard. Incredible straight-line performance with daily usability.

variants.name: GT2 RS
variants.description: The ultimate 991 with 700 hp from twin-turbo 3.8L. Rear-wheel drive, track weapon. Highly collectible.

variants.name: Targa 4 / 4S
variants.description: Distinctive power-operated Targa top with AWD. Elegant and practical.

items.detail: 991 engines can consume some oil, especially when driven hard. Monitor levels.
Check for boost leaks, wastegate operation, and proper boost pressure.
Check expansion tank and radiators for leaks. Overheating is engine-critical.
Can wear on higher-mileage cars causing vibration.
Most 991s have PDK. Check for smooth operation, proper clutch wear indication.
If equipped, test all gears. Check for synchro wear on high-mileage cars.
Verify PDK fluid has been serviced at proper intervals.
Most 991s have PASM. Test in all modes for proper damping.
If equipped with ceramic brakes, check rotor condition carefully. Extremely expensive to replace.
Can wear on track-driven or high-mileage cars.
Test for proper operation. Complex system.
Test navigation, connectivity, and all infotainment functions.
If equipped, verify all modes function including launch control.
Test full operation. Targa mechanism is complex.
Check for rock chips, especially on front fascia. Clear bra recommended.
Check for curb rash. Factory wheels are expensive to replace.
Check panels for consistent gaps and paint matching.

project.description: Higher-mileage base Carreras or cars with service needs.

driver.description: Good Carrera S or 4S examples with reasonable miles.

excellent.description: Well-maintained GT3, Turbo, or low-mileage GTS examples.

concours.description: GT3 RS, GT2 RS, or exceptional low-mileage special editions.

redFlags: PCCB brakes with visible damage or excessive wear
Evidence of track abuse without proper maintenance
PDK with shudder or transmission codes
GT cars with questionable racing history
whatToLookFor: Carrera S or GTS for best all-around package
GT3 manual for ultimate driver engagement
Sport Chrono and PASM as standard equipment
Avoid PCCB unless budget allows for replacement
Factory CPO warranty if still applicable
expertTips: The 991 is one of the most refined and capable 911s ever made
991.1 naturally aspirated engines are preferred by purists
991.2 turbo engines offer better everyday performance
GT3 with manual transmission is the enthusiast's choice
Avoid PCCB ceramic brakes if you can't afford replacement
PDK is faster but manual is more engaging
Factory CPO warranty provides excellent peace of mind
Budget for proper maintenance - these are complex cars
The 991 is reliable with proper care
GT2 RS and GT3 RS are appreciating collectibles
